tokens.line: /* This is a quick tutorial on how to quickly outline stories in Beat, introducing you to the more advanced features. */
/* This is a quick tutorial on how to quickly outline stories in Beat, introducing you to the more advanced features. */
tokens.text: This is a quick tutorial on how to quickly outline stories in Beat, introducing you to the more advanced features.

tokens.line: /* This is a quick tutorial on how to quickly outline stories in Beat, introducing you to the more advanced features. */

By default, the index card view shows an automatically created snippet. It's usually the first action paragraph in the scene. It's not ideal when at the outlining stage, so it's easy to set up your own index card content.
tokens.text: By default, the index card view shows an automatically created snippet. It's usually the first action paragraph in the scene. It's not ideal when at the outlining stage, so it's easy to set up your own index card content.

tokens.line: = A synopsis line will be displayed as the scene's content in the index card view. These lines don't print out in the final screenplay.
tokens.text: A synopsis line will be displayed as the scene's content in the index card view. These lines don't print out in the final screenplay.

tokens.line: [[You can also use a note, whichever you prefer.]]
[[You can also use a note, whichever you prefer.]]
tokens.text: You can also use a note, whichever you prefer.

tokens.line: [[You can also use a note, whichever you prefer.]]

= Setting a color for your scenes makes it easier to distinguish them from each other. Colors can be used to follow storylines, or just as markers. For example: Does a scene need work, is it maybe unimportant, or does it mark a big change for a character?
tokens.text: Setting a color for your scenes makes it easier to distinguish them from each other. Colors can be used to follow storylines, or just as markers. For example: Does a scene need work, is it maybe unimportant, or does it mark a big change for a character?

tokens.line: Did you know that you can filter scenes by their color in the **Outline View** (⌘D)?
tokens.text: Did you know that you can filter scenes by their color in the **Outline View** (⌘D)?

tokens.line: The storyline feature is still a work-in-progress, but you can test it out manually.
tokens.text: The storyline feature is still a work-in-progress, but you can test it out manually.

tokens.line: Scenes can belong to multiple storylines, too. They line out nicely in the Timeline View.
tokens.text: Scenes can belong to multiple storylines, too. They line out nicely in the Timeline View.
